html:
#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson covered multiple definitions of research data and examined the varying types of research data including associated researcher materials that need to be included alongside data to ensure they remain meaningful. It also introduced learners to two key concepts examined in this course: metadata and the research data lifecycle. Understanding the heterogeneous nature of data can help researchers and information professionals appreciate how different disciplines conceptualize data. Building a familiarity with basic data management concepts will also enable researchers and information professionals to share a common vocabulary when discussing data management.

Key Concepts & Definitions

Research data can take on many different forms, and definitions of research data can vary based on the research community.

  • The National Institutes of Health define research data as “Recorded factual material commonly accepted in the scientific community as necessary to document and support research findings” ( National Institutes of Health ).

  • The National Science Foundation’s definition describes data as something “determined by the community of interest through the process of peer review and program management” ( National Science Foundation ). Examples of data provided by NSF include data , publications, samples, physical collections, software, and models.

  • The National Endowment for the Humanities defines data as “materials generated or collected during the course of conducting research” and provides a wider variety of examples of data than NIH or NSF ( National Endowment for the Humanities ).

Key take-away: Data should be valid, shared, and are heterogeneous and contextualized within research communities.

There are other important research products that may need to be provided alongside the data in order for the data to be meaningful and to support secondary analysis. These may include codebooks, questionnaires, descriptions of methodologies, reports, conference posters, articles, white papers, websites or blogs, etc.

Metadata is defined as structured information that describes, explains, locates, and otherwise represents something else. Metadata allows data to be found and interpreted. At a minimum, one needs to know who created the data, when the data were created or published, and a title or descriptive name used to refer to the dataset. Digital data should also have a unique and persistent identifier. Two metadata standards commonly used to describe research data are Dublin Core and the Data Documentation Initiative .

Key take-away: Without supporting documentation and metadata, data may be rendered meaningless and unusable.

The research data lifecycle can be depicted in multiple different ways from simple to complex. It provides a useful way to think through the various different stages that data go through during a research project. Key phases of the research data lifecycle created by the Data Documentation Initiative include: Discovery and Planning, Initial Data Collection, Data Preparation and Analysis, Publication and Sharing, and Long-term Management.

Key take-away: Proper data management takes place across the entire research data lifecycle!

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson defined the concept of “data management”, explained why data management is an important part of the responsible conduct of research, identified key stakeholders in data management and their roles and responsibilities, and illustrated how data management fits within the research lifecycle.

Key Concepts & Definitions

Data management refers to the everyday handling and workflow of research data during the active phase of a project as well as the practices that support long-term preservation, access, and use after the project has been completed. These activities can include planning, documenting data, formatting data, storing data, anonymizing data, and controlling access to data.

Data Management, as defined by NOAA's Administrative Order 212-15, "consists of two major activities conducted in coordination: data management services and data stewardship. They constitute a comprehensive end-to-end process including movement of data and information from the observing system sensors to the data user. This process includes the acquisition, quality control, metadata cataloging, validation, reprocessing, storage, retrieval, dissemination, and archival of data.”

There are numerous reasons why data management is important. It makes it possible for other researchers to discover, interpret, and reuse data. It helps sustain the value of data by enabling others to verify and build upon published results. It facilitates long-term preservation of and access to datasets. Finally, a growing number of funding agencies, journal publishers, and research institutions require it.

Key take-away: Data management is an integral part of the responsible conduct of research. It helps researchers optimize use of data during the active phase of the research project and helps them collaborate with other researchers.

Data management stakeholders may vary depending on the setting and subject domain but often include the following:

  • Primary Researcher or Principal Investigator : Creates and uses data

  • Institution : Sets internal data management policy

  • Data Repository : Curates and provides access to data

  • User : Uses 3rd party data

  • Funder : Provides the resources to support a research project

  • Publisher : Disseminates discoveries and maintains the scientific record

Key take-away: The variety of stakeholders suggests that proper management of data throughout the research lifecycle requires communication and cooperation between these various groups.

Data Management Across the Research Lifecycle

Discovery & Planning : This is the stage to determine if a project will produce a new dataset, combine existing datasets or analyze existing datasets; identify privacy, confidentiality, and other ethical issues; consider documentation format and content and the metadata standards to use to describe the data; identify potential users of project data; identify an appropriate data repository to archive the data; and determine data management costs. These details should be included in the data management plan.

Initial Data Collection : This is the stage during which to determine workflows and procedures for organizing files, backups and storage, performing quality assurance protocols, and setting appropriate access controls and security measures.

Preparation & Data Analysis : Researchers may need to clean, manipulate, or process the raw data. What is important during this stage is to document the changes to the raw data and creating a “master” version to be analyzed and eventually archived. It is also essential to document analysis procedures such as additional modifications to the data, the model used, the code used to run the analysis, and hardware and software specifications.

Publication and Sharing : This is the stage to consult with the archive or repository to determine file formats, clean and further document data. Additionally, all documentation should be reviewed to ensure that the they contain enough information to allow the data to be re-used by a third party.

Long-term Management : This is the stage during which researchers share their data and findings through publications, submit reports, and deposit data and supplementary materials into the archive or repository.

Key take-away: Effective data management takes place during all phases of the research lifecycle from planning your project to collecting your data to preparing and analyzing your data and then finally publishing and sharing your data in a repository that will see to their long term management.

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson provided a basic overview of Data Management Plans. Most funding agencies now require grantees to submit Data Management Plans as a part of the grant proposal package. Therefore, it is important for researchers as well as information professionals supporting researchers to understand how to create a DMP. This lesson also discussed available DMP tools that can assist researchers and information professionals in the development of comprehensive DMPs.

Key Concepts & Definitions

Data Management Plans (otherwise known as DMPs) are formal documents that describe the data produced during a research project and outline data management strategies that will be implemented during and after the active phase of the research project. DMPs also describe in detail all aspects of data management that will take place during the entire research data lifecycle when data are being collected, organized, documented, shared, and preserved.

A growing number of funding agencies including the National Science Foundation, the National Institutes of Health, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Economic and Social Research Council, and the Wellcome Trust require researchers to submit Data Management Plans. Funding agencies require grantees to submit Data Management Plans because they provide assurances that data will be accessible and usable over the long term. This is important for two primary reasons:

  1. Data Management Plans support transparency and openness . Data management plans that illustrate how data will be made discoverable, accessible, and reusable support the responsibility to make publicly funded research products openly available.

  2. Data Management Plans support return on investment . Making data discoverable, accessible, and reusable maximizes the research potential of the data and provides greater returns on public investments in research.

Key take-away: Today, DMPs are required by a growing number of funding agencies. Two key reasons why funders require DMPs is to support transparency and openness and their return on investment.

The Digital Curation Centre’s Checklist for a Data Management Plan provides a useful list of questions to consider when writing a DMP:

  • What data will you collect or create?

  • How will the data be collected or created?

  • What documentation and metadata will accompany the data?

  • How will you manage any ethical issues?

  • How will you manage copyright and intellectual property rights issues?

  • How will the data be stored and backed up during research?

  • How will you manage access and security?

  • Which data should be retained, shared, and/or preserved?

  • What is the long-term preservation plan for the dataset?

  • How will you share the data?

  • Are any restrictions on data sharing required?

  • Who will be responsible for data management?

  • What resources will you require to implement your plan?

Key take-away: Writing a DMP helps researchers think through data management issues early in the research lifecycle, which can help researchers “do better research” and ensure that data will remain accessible and usable over the long-term.

Two helpful (and free!) data management planning tools available to researchers and information professionals include the DMPTool , created by the University of California Curation Center of the California Digital Library, and DMPOnline , developed by the UK Digital Curation Centre. Both of these tools provide guidance and templates for creating Data Management Plans in compliance with institutional and funder requirements. For more information on these tools check out the following videos:

DMPTool Overview Video: https://dmptool.org/video

DMPOnline Video: http://www.screenr.com/PJHN

Key take-away: You are not alone! There are numerous free, online tools available to help researchers and information professionals create Data Management Plans.

#inmemory#

Overview

In this lesson you were introduced to the importance of documenting your research data, and why and how to cite data.

Key Concepts & Definitions

There are many reasons why you need to document your data:

  • to help you remember the details later

  • to help others understand your research, verify your findings, review your submitted publication, replicate your results, or even archive your data for access and re-use.

Research data need to be documented at various levels:

  • project level

  • file or database level

  • and variable or item level.

Some examples of data documentation are:

  • laboratory notebooks

  • methodology reports

  • questionnaires

  • and software syntax.

Laboratory notebooks, for example, play an important role in supporting claims relating to intellectual property developed by researchers, and even defending against claims of scientific fraud.

Data citation promotes the reproduction of research results, allows the impact and use of data to be tracked, and provides a structure which recognises and rewards the data creator.

Key take-away: By providing good documentation and a citation for your work, you make it easier for others to re-use your data, cite your work, and give you acknowledgement in the scholarly record. When re-using others' data you should give it a proper citation as well.

Additional Resources

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson examined the benefits and challenges of sharing research data. It also illustrated the key elements found within data citations and how data citations can encourage researchers to share their data by providing a stable mechanism for acknowledgement. Understanding the culture surrounding data sharing will assist researchers in making informed decisions when sharing their data and will help information professionals clearly articulate both the benefits and challenges surrounding sharing research data.

Key Concepts & Definitions

There are multiple benefits to sharing data including supporting transparency and openness and increasing the return on investment for publicly funded research. Below are additional benefits to individual researchers and the broader research community:

  1. Sharing data reinforces open scientific inquiry

  2. Sharing data supports the verification and replication of original results

  3. Sharing data promotes new research and allows for the testing of new or alternative methods

  4. Sharing data encourages collaboration and multiple perspectives

  5. Sharing data provides important teaching resources

  6. Sharing data reduces cost by avoiding duplicate data collection efforts

  7. Sharing data protects against faulty or fraudulent data

  8. Sharing data enhances the visibility and overall impact of research projects

  9. Sharing data preserves data for future use

  10. Sharing data helps the broader community and individual researchers “do better research”

Key take-away: Sharing research data not only allows researchers to comply with funder mandates, but it also has the potential to produce broader career and scientific benefits.

Despite these benefits, researchers may be reticent to share their data due to the multiple challenges commonly associated with data sharing. Below are some challenges that researchers often cite:

  1. Time and effort to make data shareable.

  2. Perceived risks that accompany losing control of the data.

  3. Presence of confidential or sensitive information in datasets.

  4. Unclear or problematic ownership of the data.

  5. Lack of incentives for sharing data.

These challenges are not always easily overcome; however, having knowledge of data management best practices can assist researchers and information professionals in addressing these challenges.

Key take-away: There are very real challenges that accompany data sharing; however, the benefits of sharing make it worthwhile to attempt to overcome these challenges.

One of the challenges related to sharing research data is the lack of career incentives for researchers. A strategy being implemented within the field of data curation to address this challenge is encouraging the creation of and use of data citations.

Data citation provides a standardized method for secondary users to cite data. It also allows researchers to reference data as standalone research products, gain acknowledgement for archiving and sharing data, and track the usage and impact of their data.

The Joint Declaration of Data Citation Principles has established eight principles to guide the development of data citations. These principles are: importance, credit and attribution, evidence, unique identification, access, persistence, specificity and verifiability, and interoperability and flexibility.

Key take-away: Data citation can help researchers gain proper acknowledgement and career benefits for sharing their data. Cite the data!

References

Piwowar, H. A. (2011). Who shares? Who doesn’t? Factors associated with openly archiving raw research data. PLoS ONE , 6 (7), e18657. http://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0018657

Piwowar, H. A., & Vision, T. J. (2013). Data reuse and the open data citation advantage. PeerJ , 1. http://doi.org/10.7287/peerj.preprints.1

Van de Sompel, H., Payette, S., Erickson, J., Lagoze, C., & Warner, S. (2004). Rethinking scholarly communication. D-Lib Magazine , 10 (9). http://doi.org/10.1045/september2004-vandesompel

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson further examined considerations in sharing data. Specifically, this lesson presented strategies for protecting confidentiality, discussed how data ownership can affect data sharing, and examined different types of access restrictions that may be placed on data as well as how to enable data sharing through the application of a standard license. Understanding how to overcome some of these challenges will empower researchers and information professionals to develop strategies for responsible data sharing in accordance with ethical and legal requirements.

Key Concepts & Definitions

There are multiple types of information that researchers need to protect when collecting, handling, storing and sharing data to ensure the privacy of participants. Three key types of information include:

Personally Identifiable Information: Any representation of information that permits the identity of an individual to whom the information applies to be reasonably inferred by either direct or indirect means ( U.S. Department of Labor ).

Protected Health Information: Individually identifiable health information transmitted or maintained in any form or medium by a covered entity ( U.S. Department of Health and Human Services ).

Sensitive Information: Information that if disclosed there is a significant likelihood of psychological, social, emotional, physical, or reputational harm.

Identifiers may be direct, indirect, or geographic . Although identifiers that directly reference an individual (e.g., social security number, name) may seem to be the most problematic, indirect identifiers can make unique cases more visible, particularly when combined with other individual attributes such as race or income. Therefore, protecting confidentiality requires careful consideration and special handling of not only direct identifiers but also indirect identifiers.

When collecting information from individuals it is also important to gain informed consent from participants that provides details about what you will do with the data, who will have access to the data, and how the data will be shared.

Different jurisdictions have different laws that govern how confidential information is managed and a subject’s privacy is protected. Three key laws in the United States include the Federal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects ("Common Rule"), the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), and the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Privacy Rule.

A common strategy for sharing data that contains confidential information is through de-identification or anonymization. There are several strategies for the de-identification of data including simply removing problematic variables or applying statistical techniques such as top-coding, collapsing or combining, sampling, swapping, or disturbing the data. In the case of qualitative data, redaction of information should take place according to a pre-planned anonymization scheme. To determine the best strategy for anonymization, it is important to consider future research questions and carefully consider a variable’s analytic importance.

Key take-away: Researchers have an ethical responsibility to protect the confidentiality of study participants! In order to openly share data, a comprehensive anonymization plan should be developed that carefully considers how participants could be identified, both directly and indirectly, as well as how anonymization may affect potential reuse.

Data ownership and intellectual property rights can also present challenges for sharing research data. Collaborative projects, institutional policies, and funder policies can all potentially affect data ownership. It is important in collaborative projects to come to agreements early concerning how and when data will be shared. It is also important to determine how any institutional or funder policies might affect data ownership and sharing. If a researcher has used extant proprietary data, then permission will have to be gained prior to sharing the data. These complexities could even lead to confusion over who actually “owns” the data.

Key take-away: To effectively share data, resolve any data ownership or intellectual property rights issues early. Consult your institution or a legal professional to determine what policies might affect data ownership and sharing.

While it is suggested that data be made as open as possible to encourage reuse, in some cases it may be necessary to place access restrictions on data. Three common types of restrictions include:

Embargos: Access to data is restricted for a specified period of time often based on a researcher’s need to have sufficient time to publish using his or her data prior to releasing them publicly.

Technological Access Restrictions: Authentication or membership with a certain research group or institution is required to access certain data.

Data Use Agreements: Users of data are required to complete an agreement that explicitly outlines rules related to the reuse, storage, re-dissemination, and disposal of data. These are commonly required when data have the potential to identify human subjects either directly or indirectly.

Access restrictions should be clearly outlined in the Terms of Use, it is also suggested to apply a standard license. An increasingly common strategy for applying a license is through assigning a standard Creative Commons license. Creative Commons 5 main license categories include: Attribution (CC BY), Non-commercial (CC BY-NC), No derivative works (CC BY-ND), Sharealike (CC BY-SA), and CC-Zero (CC0). Creative Commons has an online tool that can help users select an appropriate license and generate text to apply the license. Researchers should also discuss possible access restrictions and licensing with their repository of choice to clarify their needs and also determine the types of licenses supported by the repository.

Key take-away: While it is suggested that researchers make data as open as possible; this may not always be possible. Clearly outlining any access restrictions within a Terms of Use and applying a standard license can help enable informed and responsible reuse .

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson examined the preservation needs of research data and identified some of the key risks related to preserving digital data. It also defined the concepts of authenticity and integrity, presented three types of metadata, and discussed how “good metadata” supports data discovery, preservation, and reuse. Understanding key concepts related to effective data preservation will assist researchers and information professionals in implementing strategies to ensure data remain accessible and understandable into the long-term future.

Key Concepts & Definitions

There are multiple risks that can lead to the loss of digital data. Four of the main risks include benign neglect, bit rot, obsolescence, and insufficient documentation.

Benign neglect: If an active preservation strategy is not in place, data may become unusable over time. Digital data requires layers of technology to access, read, and render the data from physical storage media. Without you knowing it, data over time are subject to degradation.

Bit rot: Digital data, which are represented as bits (or units of machine-readable information) may degrade or become corrupted over time causing decreased, delayed, or faulty rendering of data.

Obsolescence: As time progresses, software and hardware become obsolete. Some approaches to avoid the risks associated with obsolescence include monitoring changes in technology, migration of files to current formats, and normalization of files to non-proprietary formats.

Insufficient Documentation: Without appropriate documentation (i.e., codebooks, questionnaires, descriptive metadata, lab instruments, etc.), data may be impossible to interpret in the future.

Key take-away: Data are at risk if not properly preserved - a trustworthy repository can assist in combating these risks!

Two primary goals of digital preservation are to safeguard the authenticity and integrity of content.

Authenticity is defined as “the quality of being genuine, not a counterfeit, and free from tampering, and is typically inferred from internal and external evidence, including its physical characteristics, structure, content, and context.” ( Society of American Archivists, 2012 ).

A few key tasks that researchers can undertake to protect the authenticity of data files include maintaining a single master file of the data, regulating write-access to master versions, recording all changes to master files, and developing a formal procedure for the destruction of master files (see the full list on the UK Data Archive website ). Repositories can protect authenticity of files by collecting and preserving descriptive and contextual metadata, documenting any operations performed on the data, and validating that any transformed or modified versions of the data are representative of the original.

Integrity can be defined as a digital object that “has not been corrupted over time or in transit; in other words, that we have in hand the same set of sequences of bits that came into existence when the object was created.” ( Lynch, 2000, “Integrity,” para. 1 )

Some key tasks that both researchers and repositories can perform to protect the integrity of digital data include backing up critical or frequently used files using an automated backup process, storing master files in non-proprietary formats, verifying backup copies of files against original files by comparing the checksum value, file size, and date, storing copies of files on two different storage media, and copying or migrating files to new storage media every 2 to 5 years.

Key take-away: Protecting the authenticity and integrity of digital data involves processes undertaken by both the researcher and the repository.

Finally, effectively preserving digital data requires the assignment and collection of metadata. Metadata refers to structured information that describes, explains, locates, or otherwise represents something and is necessary for resource discovery, organization of electronic resources, interoperability across systems, digital identification of data, and archiving and preserving data ( National Information Standards Organization, 2004 ).

There are three main types of metadata: descriptive, administrative, and structural.

Descriptive metadata : Describes a work for the purposes of discovery and identification.

Administrative metadata : Structured information regarding the management and tracking of data over a period of time. There are two main types of administrative metadata: rights management and preservation.

Structural metadata : Describes the physical or logical structure of digital objects.

Many metadata standards often specify representation rules and/or controlled vocabularies for metadata entries, these standards are important for creating “good metadata.” Good standardized metadata also supports interoperability, which is the “ability of multiple systems with different hardware and software platforms, data structures, and interfaces to exchange data with a minimal loss of content and functionality” ( National Information Standards Organization, 2004, p. 2 ). An example of an interoperability framework that relies upon “good metadata” to share metadata across distributed systems is the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting (OAI-PMH) .

Key take-away: Good metadata is standardized, consistent, and interoperable and facilitates discovery, preservation, and archiving of data.

#inmemory#

Overview

This lesson examined the role of trustworthy repositories in archiving and preserving research data including how repositories can demonstrate their trustworthiness through audit and certification. It also used the OAIS Reference Model as a framework to discuss repository workflows, procedures, and best practices. Understanding the processes undertaken by repository’s to archive and preserve research data will help researchers assess the trustworthiness of repositories and select an appropriate repository for their data. Building increased knowledge of data archiving standards and best practices will also assist information professionals in supporting the increasing data curation needs of the research community.

Key Concepts & Definitions

According to an RLG-OCLC Report, “a trusted digital repository is one whose mission is to provide reliable long-term access to managed digital resources to its designated community, now and in the future” ( RLG/OCLC, 2002, p. 5 ). Repositories demonstrate their trustworthiness through compliance with standards and best practices, transparent and well-documented policies and procedures, and audit and certification. Policies and procedures communicate a repository’s services and capabilities - essential information to assist researchers in selecting a repository appropriate for their data. In addition, audit and certification provide assurances to researchers that their data will be properly cared for.

Three examples of audits and/or certifications include DRAMBORA (self-audit), the Data Seal of Approval (self-assessment and peer review), and the ISO 16363 Audit and Certification of Trustworthy Digital Repositories (external audit). Other certifications include the International Council for Science World Data System Certification and the Nestor Seal for Trustworthy Digital Archives .

Key take-away: There is no one-size fits all repository. Researchers should assess a repository’s services and strengths to determine the best home for their data!

At the foundation of many archival standards is ISO 14721 Reference Model for an Open Archival Information System , or OAIS. The OAIS model presents a high-level framework for understanding archival concepts, defines elements and processes within digital repositories, and establishes a set of responsibilities for the long-term preservation of digital information. Below are the six OAIS functional entities including brief descriptions:

Ingest : Establishes evidence of authenticity and ensures that files within the Submission Information Package (SIP) are in proper formats and include necessary documentation. Data repositories may also perform additional tasks such as checks for confidential information and data quality reviews.

Archival Storage : Provisions storage, maintenance, and retrieval of the Archival Information Package (AIP), manages storage hierarchy, performs error checking, refreshes storage media, and recovers files.

Data Management : Provides functionality for generating, maintaining, and accessing descriptive information and administers database functions.

Administration : Handles data submission agreements, establishes quality standards, and manages infrastructure configurations.

Preservation : Provides recommendations for preservation planning strategies (often including migration and/or emulation), recommends changes to archive processes and policies, reports any risks, and monitors the technology landscape and users’ service requirements.

Access : Coordinates access requests and delivers the Dissemination Information Package (DIP) to users.

Trustworthy repositories not only have workflows and policies in accordance with standards, such as OAIS, they also demonstrate organizational, physical, and economic stability. A trustworthy repository can weather the storm of personnel transitions, infrastructure mishaps, and tightly resourced environments without any disruption in preservation activities.

Key take-away: Archiving data properly is no trivial undertaking! Trustworthy repositories expend significant labor, funding, research, and assessment to safeguard the data deposited with them.
